document_metadata.description: Heme BEL model is a disease model based on Biological Expression Language (BEL) containing the core mechanisms of heme as modulator in Hemolytic diseases such as sickle-cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, malaria and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
document_metadata.name: heme_27515135.bel

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Plasma hemoglobin scavenges nitric oxide and causes vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation and inflammation9,22–24.

links.evidence: Plasma hemoglobin scavenges nitric oxide and causes vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation and inflammation9,22–24.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Toxicity of free hemoglobin is also caused by the release of cell-free heme, which produces lipid peroxidation and mitochondrial damage and increases the production of reactive oxygen species.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: In mice resuscitated with SRBCs, plasma hemoglobin levels were greater than in mice resuscitated with FRBCs or in sham-treated mice at two, four, and 24 hours after transfusion (Figure 1C).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The plasma hemoglobin levels at two and four hours after SRBC-transfusion were greater than the cell-free hemoglobin levels in the supernatant of the SRBCs before transfusion (Figure 1C, Supplemental Table I), providing evidence that hemolysis occurs in vivo during and after transfusion of SRBCs.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Co-administration of haptoglobin with SRBCs results in a prolonged increase in plasma hemoglobin levels for more than 48 hours after transfusion.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: These results demonstrate that transfusion with SRBCs and simultaneous infusion of exogenous hemopexin results in decreased levels of circulating cell-free heme.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: After resuscitation with SRBCs, only 58% of mice survived for 48 hours (SRBC vs. FRBC, P<0.05).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: In mice resuscitated with SRBCs, plasma hemoglobin levels were greater than in mice resuscitated with FRBCs or in sham-treated mice at two, four, and 24 hours after transfusion (Figure 1C).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The plasma hemoglobin levels at two and four hours after SRBC-transfusion were greater than the cell-free hemoglobin levels in the supernatant of the SRBCs before transfusion (Figure 1C, Supplemental Table I), providing evidence that hemolysis occurs in vivo during and after transfusion of SRBCs.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: In animals resuscitated with SRBCs, plasma hemopexin levels significantly decreased from 147.1±11.4 mg/dl at baseline to 86.7±12.2 and 76.3±5. 4 mg/dl at two and four hours after resuscitation, respectively (p<0.05 for both, Figure 2A).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The increase in plasma haptoglobin levels from baseline to 48 hours after resuscitation was less in mice transfused with SRBCs compared to mice transfused with FRBCs (P<0.001).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Hemoglobinuria was noted in mice resuscitated with SRBCs alone but not mice resuscitated with FRBCs or sham-treated mice (Figure 4A and B).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Markers of renal damage, including kidney KIM-1 and NGAL mRNA levels, urinary KIM-1 protein levels, and plasma NGAL concentration, were greater in mice after resuscitation with SRBCs or SRBCs and albumin than in mice transfused with FRBCs (Figures 4C–F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Markers of renal damage, including kidney KIM-1 and NGAL mRNA levels, urinary KIM-1 protein levels, and plasma NGAL concentration, were greater in mice after resuscitation with SRBCs or SRBCs and albumin than in mice transfused with FRBCs (Figures 4C–F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Markers of renal damage, including kidney KIM-1 and NGAL mRNA levels, urinary KIM-1 protein levels, and plasma NGAL concentration, were greater in mice after resuscitation with SRBCs or SRBCs and albumin than in mice transfused with FRBCs (Figures 4C–F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Kidney sections of mice resuscitated with SRBCs showed more cortical Ki-67 positive cells per 20× field (1.08 mm field diameter) than those of mice resuscitated with FRBCs (SRBC vs. FRBC: 156.2±10.4 vs. 56.4±4.7, p<0.01).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Tissue iron staining revealed greater cortical iron accumulation in the kidneys of mice resuscitated with SRBCs, SRBCs combined with albumin and SRBCs combined with hemopexin than in the kidneys of mice transfused with FRBCs (Figure 6A and B).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Splenic iron content was greater in mice after resuscitation with SRBCs than in FRBC-transfused mice.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Taken together, these results indicate that haptoglobin co-transfusion prevented stored blood transfusion-associated renal iron uptake and led to increased weight and greater iron- accumulation in the spleens of mice.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Liver damage, measured by plasma levels of alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST) at 48 hours after resuscitation, was greater after resuscitation with SRBCs compared to resuscitation with FRBCs (Figure 6E and F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Liver damage, measured by plasma levels of alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST) at 48 hours after resuscitation, was greater after resuscitation with SRBCs compared to resuscitation with FRBCs (Figure 6E and F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: After resuscitation with SRBCs, only 58% of mice survived for 48 hours (SRBC vs. FRBC, P<0.05).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: In contrast, all of the mice survived after SRBC-transfusion and treatment with hemopexin (SRBC+Hx vs. SRBC+Alb, P=0.018). Similarly the survival rate of mice resuscitated with SRBCs and co-infusion of haptoglobin was 96% (SRBC+Hp vs. SRBC+Alb, P=0.030).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Infusion of hemopexin together with SRBCs resulted in a 6.4-fold (95% CI [5.2 – 7.6]) increase in plasma hemopexin levels at four hours after transfusion (Figure 3D).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The increase in hemopexin was associated with decreased plasma heme levels (Figure 3I).

links.evidence: The increase in plasma haptoglobin levels from baseline to 48 hours after resuscitation was less in mice transfused with SRBCs compared to mice transfused with FRBCs (P<0.001).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Infusion of hemopexin together with SRBCs resulted in a 6.4-fold (95% CI [5.2 – 7.6]) increase in plasma hemopexin levels at four hours after transfusion (Figure 3D).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: These results demonstrate that transfusion with SRBCs and simultaneous infusion of exogenous hemopexin results in decreased levels of circulating cell-free heme.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Tissue iron staining revealed greater cortical iron accumulation in the kidneys of mice resuscitated with SRBCs, SRBCs combined with albumin and SRBCs combined with hemopexin than in the kidneys of mice transfused with FRBCs (Figure 6A and B).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The renal expression level of IL-6 was greater 48 hours after resuscitation with SRBCs alone, SRBC and albumin, and SRBCs and hemopexin when compared to resuscitation with FRBCs (Supplemental Figure VI D).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Mice that were resuscitated with SRBCs and albumin or SRBCs and hemopexin showed a marked increase in HO-1 expression when compared to mice resuscitated with FRBCs.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: In contrast, all of the mice survived after SRBC-transfusion and treatment with hemopexin (SRBC+Hx vs. SRBC+Alb, P=0.018). Similarly the survival rate of mice resuscitated with SRBCs and co-infusion of haptoglobin was 96% (SRBC+Hp vs. SRBC+Alb, P=0.030).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Co-administration of haptoglobin with SRBCs results in a prolonged increase in plasma hemoglobin levels for more than 48 hours after transfusion.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Hemoglobinuria was present in mice resuscitated with SRBCs combined with albumin or hemopexin but not in mice resuscitated with SRBCs combined with haptoglobin (Figure 4A and B).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Co-infusion of haptoglobin but not albumin or hemopexin prevented SRBC-induced hemoglobinuria and kidney injury at 48 hours after resuscitation from hemorrhagic shock.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: However, kidney KIM-1 and NGAL mRNA levels, urinary KIM-1 protein levels and NGAL plasma concentrations in mice transfused with SRBCs and haptoglobin were lower than in mice transfused with SRBCs given a co-infusion of albumin (Figures 4C–F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: However, kidney KIM-1 and NGAL mRNA levels, urinary KIM-1 protein levels and NGAL plasma concentrations in mice transfused with SRBCs and haptoglobin were lower than in mice transfused with SRBCs given a co-infusion of albumin (Figures 4C–F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: However, kidney KIM-1 and NGAL mRNA levels, urinary KIM-1 protein levels and NGAL plasma concentrations in mice transfused with SRBCs and haptoglobin were lower than in mice transfused with SRBCs given a co-infusion of albumin (Figures 4C–F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The number of Ki-67 positive cells in kidneys from mice that received SRBCs and haptoglobin was similar to the number of Ki-67 positive cells in kidneys from mice that received FRBCs..

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Only transfusion of SRBCs and haptoglobin prevented SRBC-induced renal iron accumulation (Figure 6A and B).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: In comparison to mice transfused with SRBCs alone, the spleens of mice resuscitated with SRBCs and haptoglobin contained more iron (Figure 6D).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Resuscitation with SRBCs and haptoglobin prevented the increase in SRBC-induced renal HO-1 expression (Figure 7F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Without adjusting for multiple comparison testing, IL-6 expression was lower in kidneys of mice resuscitated with SRBCs and haptoglobin compared to mice resuscitated with SRBCs and albumin (P<0.05).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Resuscitation with SRBCs together with albumin did not alter plasma levels of hemoglobin, hemopexin, haptoglobin, or heme as compared to resuscitation with SRBCs alone (Figure 3C–E, I, Supplemental Material and Supplemental Figure II A–B).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Liver damage, measured by plasma levels of alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST) at 48 hours after resuscitation, was greater after resuscitation with SRBCs compared to resuscitation with FRBCs (Figure 6E and F).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The renal expression level of IL-6 was greater 48 hours after resuscitation with SRBCs alone, SRBC and albumin, and SRBCs and hemopexin when compared to resuscitation with FRBCs (Supplemental Figure VI D).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: The renal expression level of IL-6 was greater 48 hours after resuscitation with SRBCs alone, SRBC and albumin, and SRBCs and hemopexin when compared to resuscitation with FRBCs (Supplemental Figure VI D).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Without adjusting for multiple comparison testing, IL-6 expression was lower in kidneys of mice resuscitated with SRBCs and haptoglobin compared to mice resuscitated with SRBCs and albumin (P<0.05).

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Mice that were resuscitated with SRBCs and albumin or SRBCs and hemopexin showed a marked increase in HO-1 expression when compared to mice resuscitated with FRBCs.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Mice that were resuscitated with SRBCs and albumin or SRBCs and hemopexin showed a marked increase in HO-1 expression when compared to mice resuscitated with FRBCs.

citation.name: Haptoglobin or Hemopexin Therapy Prevents Acute Adverse Effects of Resuscitation After Prolonged Storage of Red Cells.

links.evidence: Resuscitation with SRBCs and haptoglobin prevented the increase in SRBC-induced renal HO-1 expression (Figure 7F).
